text: whoopos meant to reply
my boy <@U039PUBV59N> figured it out
do tell
the explorer generates its own api key with all scopes , which makes sense
ah interesting

so it can access anything, wheres any external requests you obv need the more granular scopes...

problem was it wasn't returning any error with that query with what I was using, somehow Niko got it to trigger a error
And it doesn't give you an error for invalid scopes
not with how I was doing it, Niko threw it in an additional object to I imagine force a error and thats when it did lol
so mix of user error and bad error reporting :crying_cat_face:
got it, very interesting
good to know, I know it throws and error if one of the parent queries doesn't have the scopes
yeah, it wasn't throwing a error because it still returns something
even if its null, which iis kinda.....backwards
I rather it just give the error

so lesson:

with HubSpots graphql, if it errors out it'll still return a 200 success but you need to look for the error anwyays
which is a tremendous waste of processing power
but not my wallet paying for it lol

I was about to reply to your other posts to investigate further <@U04N6N424MB>, but I'm glad you all managed to figure it out. I can file something on our end regarding this bug to make the scope error more apparent. Thanks for reporting it!
no worries thank yu for your help
i wish we had a form to submit somewheres so we didnt have to go through HS Support...it took twnety minutes of explaining to the guy what graphql is to get him to even escalate it
